body_text.text: Since COVID-19 was discovered in China in late 2019, cases have spread far and wide and 38 are putting a strain on healthcare systems in many countries. Data from China indicate that while 39 81% of patients had mild cases, 14% of cases were severe and 5% were critical. (1, 2) . The 40 overall case fatality rate (CFR) in China for 55,924 confirmed cases was 3.8% (3) with 41 increased rates in adults with comorbid conditions including cardiovascular disease (CVD; 42 CFR=13.2%, diabetes (9.2%), chronic respiratory disease (8.0%), hypertension (8.4%), and 43 cancer (7.6%); the case fatality rate for those with none of these comorbid conditions was 1.4%

(3). We found that 45.4% of US adults, with a wide range across age groups and states, may be 130 at heightened risk of complications from COVID-19 due to existing comorbid conditions. And 131 while the rates increase with age group to about 80% among those ages 70 and older, due to the 132 fact that the majority (71%) of US adults is younger than age 60, 53% of those at heightened risk 133 of complications are also younger than age 60 years. That is consistent with the finding that 134 >60% of adults with multiple (2 or more) chronic conditions were younger than age 65 (7).

Many of these younger adults with comorbid conditions may require hospitalization for these 136 complications. Results in Tables 1 and 2 may be helpful to localities planning healthcare system 137 needs for COVID-19. The median value of having any of the co-morbidities for all states is 138 45.3, for planning purposes, states with rates in Table 1 that are above 45.3 might require 139 proportionally more ICU beds and ventilators than those with rates below 45.3.

Currently there is a dearth of data on adults at risk for complications from COVID-19 that 141 can be used for comparison. One source is a recent report from the Kaiser Foundation (8) that 142 found 41% of US adults at risk of serious illness from COVID-19, defined as all adults ages 60 143 and older and those 18-59 years with heart disease, cancer, COPD, or diabetes. Note that 144 hypertension, which is the most common comorbid condition, was omitted in that study (8).

In a recent US study that included all these 152 comorbid conditions except cancer, obesity was a major contributor to diabetes, hypertension,153    and asthma and at least an indirect contributor to CVD (10). Other risk factors also contribute to 154 these comorbid conditions (11) and will have different prevalence rates in different countries and 155 population groups within countries.156The list of chronic conditions used in our analysis is very similar to groups at increased risk 157 for seasonal influenza complications (12) except that latter group includes obese adults and158 children <2 years and excludes people with hypertension. Both lists include people with chronic 159 diseases for which behavioral risk factors have been well identified (10,11). Behavioral risk 160 factors appear to be very common among US adults with >95% of all adults reporting one or 161 more (10) of the 7 CVD risk factors of smoking, sedentary lifestyle, obesity, diabetes, 162 hypertension, high cholesterol, and inadequate fruit and vegetable consumption. Results from 163 that study (10) found those 7 risk factors together contributed to an average of 41.4% of the 164 burden of 5 of the 6 comorbidities (all except cancer) used in this current study, with obesity and 165 smoking contributing the most.

Only 175 non-institutionalized adults are surveyed so 1.3 million adults in nursing homes (13) were 176 excluded which almost certainly underestimates risk, as the first death in the US from COVID-177 19 was a nursing home resident (14). Data are self-reported and reliability and validity can vary 178 for different measures tested (6). But as long as a respondent was told they had a chronic 179 condition, validity was high. Low response rates could introduce bias but, as noted, validity 180 appears high for the measures used in this study. Results are specific for this coronavirus in the 181 US. 182 Conclusion: These results indicating 45.4% of adults are at potentially heightened risk of 183 complications from COVID-19 due to chronic conditions should help state health officials in 184 estimating health care needs. The US may never determine an accurate case fatality rate but it 185 appears likely that it would be greater than the 3.8% reported for China. It should also be clear 186 that while adults ages 70 and older are at higher risk it is because they are more likely to have the 187 chronic conditions identified as increasing risk but that the majority of adults at risk are actually 188 younger than age 70.

Overall 45.4% (95% CI 45.1-45.7) of respondents reported one or more of the 6 comorbidities and were considered at heightened risk or more. Prevalence rates of the separate comorbidities were 8.5% for CVD, 6.6% for COPD, 109 9.1% for asthma, 10.8% for diabetes, 32.4% for hypertension, and 6.8% for cancer.
